statement:
Let $U \subset \mathbb{C}$ be a simply connected domain, and suppose $f$
is a complex valued function which is defined and analytic on all but
finitely many points $a_1, \dots, a_m$ of $U$. Let $C$ be a closed curve
in $U$ which does not intersect any of the $a_i$. Then
$$\int_C f(z)\ dz = 2 \pi i \sum_{i=1}^m \eta(C,a_i) \operatorname{Res}(f;a_i),$$
where $$\eta(C,a_i) := \frac{1}{2 \pi i} \int_C \frac{dz}{z-a_i}$$ is
the winding number of $C$ about $a_i$, and $\operatorname{Res}(f;a_i)$
denotes the residue of $f$ at $a_i$.

The Cauchy residue theorem generalizes both the Cauchy integral theorem
(because analytic functions have no poles) and the Cauchy integral
formula (because $f(x)/(x-a)^n$ for analytic $f$ has exactly one pole at
$x=a$ with residue
$\operatorname{Res}(f(x)/(x-a)^n,a) = f^{(n)}(a)/n!)$.
